results.title: Spiceworld: the movie
results.creator_credit: Fragile Films, Uri Fruchtmann, Barnaby Thompson and Bob Spiers
results.brief_description: A thriller with a little romance and a lot of comedy, “Spiceworld” chronicles the five crazy days leading to the Spice Girls’ first live concert at the Royal Albert Hall. Photojournalists follow as they travel from press conferences to practice sessions to photo shoots, passing London landmarks in the comfort of their tardis Spicebus and emerging into a musical cascade of colour, trendy clothes and blinding flashbulbs. Exploring the trials and tribulations of their global fame, “Spiceworld” takes a satirical stab at the media giants and commercial junkies who relentlessly compete to manufacture the girls’ success or demise. Cast includes The Spice Girls, Richard E. Grant, Alan Cumming, George Wendt, Claire Rushbrook and Roger Moore.

results.title: Spherical mirrors
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Rank and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Light”.
Explains the basic properties of convex and concave mirrors, contrasting real and virtual image formation, and illustrates practical applications.

results.title: Spheres
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Rene Jodoin
results.brief_description: A play on motion, against a background of multi-hued sky. Spheres of translucent pearl seem to float weightlessly in the unlimited panorama of the sky, grouping, regrouping, at times colliding like some stylised burst of the atomic chain reaction. Set to the music of Bach, played by pianist Glenn Gould. (Awards: Cordoba)

results.title: Sperm cell development in the grasshopper
results.brief_description: This film is chiefly interesting as an example of the use of film in the service of science, in this case, microcinematography. Living cells are shown developing by the use of phase contrast microscopy, a method due to Zernicke, which gives increased contrast by optical means, and without staining.

results.title: Spend and prosper: a portrait of John Maynard Keynes
results.creator_credit: Christopher La Fontaine and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Traces the life of John Maynard Keynes through the eyes of some of the people who knew and worked with him. They include Quentin Bell, J.K. Galbraith and Ninette de Valois. Also spells out some of his economic theories which are in direct opposition to the monetarist policies followed by today’s (1980’s) governments. Narrated by Paul Vaughan.

results.title: Spelling it out
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Sabina Baltrukomis
results.brief_description: Shows the teaching of spelling in primary schools from the nineteenth century to the present day. Could be used in conjunction with the Victorian Education Department’s booklet “The Teaching of spelling”. Changing attitudes and a variety of teaching methods are also looked at.

results.title: Spellbound (2002)
results.creator_credit: Thinkfilm, Home Box Office, Jeffrey Blitz and Sean Welch
results.brief_description: This Academy Award nominated documentary focuses on eight children competing in a championship spelling bee. We see behind the scenes meeting the finalists and their families. The tension of the competition is gripping as is looking into the varying backgrounds of the contestants. The high pressure world of the spelling bee and the pressure placed on the contestants can cause a sweat in not only the contestant and their parents but also the viewer. Gruelling competition and high drama are found in this compelling documentary. Having the background knowledge on the competitors adds to the overall enjoyment. Notable is the fact that the winners in most cases are from ethnic backgrounds who are willing to work hard and succeed. There is certainly a great deal of face pulling and mental strain in this moving and exciting film.

results.title: Spellbound
results.creator_credit: David O. Selznick and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: Ingrid Bergman plays Dr. Peterson, a detached and brilliant psychiatrist who falls helplessly in love with Dr. Edwards, played by Gregory Peck, only to find he is an amnesiac and imposter suspected of murdering the true Dr. Edwards.

constellations_other.name: Good vibrations
constellations_other.description: Since its invention, the humble theremin has been used in a number of different ways to evoke all sorts of strange sounds and moods.

results.description: Ingrid Bergman plays Dr. Peterson, a detached and brilliant psychiatrist who falls helplessly in love with Dr. Edwards, played by Gregory Peck, only to find he is an amnesiac and imposter suspected of murdering the true Dr. Edwards. She sets out to prove his innocence, becoming a fugitive herself. Through skilful detective work, she manages to access the dark and confused chambers of his mind finding the clues which help her unravel this perplexing mystery.
description_for_label: Ingrid Bergman plays Dr. Peterson, a detached and brilliant psychiatrist who falls helplessly in love with Dr. Edwards, played by Gregory Peck, only to find he is an amnesiac and imposter suspected of murdering the true Dr. Edwards. She sets out to prove his innocence, becoming a fugitive herself. Through skilful detective work, she manages to access the dark and confused chambers of his mind finding the clues which help her unravel this perplexing mystery.
